comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Thanks AB! The Will Daley election poster fragment by the lane, is clear in the original prints of the photo - which I saw when choosing my Christmas present: www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet/5476045214/ www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet/5476050098/ I've now gathered together so many photographs with Will Daley election posters, it has necessitated the creation of a second part to the gallery. I'm certain there are more to find! [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet/galleries/72157626241607052/]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: If Will Daley was standing in the upcoming NSW election, would you vote for him?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: By my calculations this is near the NW corner of  Little Essex Street.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: 1. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] As a young and idealistic first time candidate, personally well-known and highly respected by the people of his electorate, I certainly would, whether or not his party was disintegrating around him. But then again, if W. E. Johnson was running too, I'd be in a bit of a dilemma, as I'd likely know him through our mutual interest in photographing Sydney (he'd likely be a contact on Flickr!) :) 2. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] A quick consult of The Plan Showing the "Rocks" Resumption confirms your calculations are spot on. The lane is Little Essex Street running down towards Upper Fort Street.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
1. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet]  Ha!  I don't think I would trust W.E. Johnson as a pollie - it is difficult to trust someone who has a tendency to date his artworks a little earlier than they are!

2. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet]  Beg to differ - the laneway (for which I know you have a special fondness and fascination) is the dotted line marked on the map between 91 and 89 (it is not easy to read).

I wonder if John Degotardi Junior (the photographer) was joking with his title "95 1/2"?

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Hmmm ... not 100% convinced by the dotted line theory. My thinking is that the "1/2" might refer to part of 97 showing at the left of the picture, and 97 is on the south side of Little Essex.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
I was wrong before on the following photo, thinking it is the SW corner of Princes and <u>Essex</u> Streets.  Comparison with the map above shows it as mistaken - entrance to the Technical School and no Wesleyan Church do not match up.  So I believe it is the SW corner of Princes and <u>Little Essex</u> Streets, ie no.97 up. - 
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2632254683/] Dated 11 September 1901 and see the companion photo of the Garrison Church at the Persistent URL.

Also the maps and photos show Little Essex Street as fairly wide, though I can't find the exact section.  Here is the SE corner -
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2376889534/]

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Aha! That clinches it - your theory is proved. As you said, no entrance to the school as would be expected if that photo was showing south of Essex. I'm glad that's sorted. :)

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Also glad!   We need a photo of the NW corner (no.106 down) to complete the confusion!

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Note the corresponding wall and fence at right of photo. We're on the bridge over the Argyle Cut! - No 41 Princes Street; Beehive Hostel (before 1930) by Hall & Co. [SLNSW: hall_35212] more pics - recordsearch.naa.gov.au/scripts/PhotoSearchItemDetail.asp... www.slv.vic.gov.au/pictoria/gid/slv-pic-aab69753/1/b28034 www3.photosau.com/cos1/scripts/ExtSearch.asp?SearchTerm=0... www3.photosau.com/cos1/scripts/ExtSearch.asp?SearchTerm=0...

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content:
Note the corresponding buildings at the top of the stairs -
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/5061232836/]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] B R I L L I A N T I S S I M O ! And the tree (bunyah pine?) behind - now looking very familiar - there were so few trees around. And guess what that corner house is numbered as on the map ? "951/2" ! It looks like the house (No.39) was divided into two houses, which may account for the very odd numbering. Unless the photographer (like me) had trouble reading the map, and it should be "39 1/2" ?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw] Any chance you could check the original map to see what is written there, please?

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] I checked the 600dpi version and the number on the corner of Princes Street and Argyle Street is 39 1/2 not 95 1/2. So the numbers are 37, 39, 39 1/2 and 41 on opposite corner. Looking further up the street, following the numbers there doesn't seem to be a number 95. No. 93 is on the corner of Princes and Little Essex and then it  jumps to No. 97 on the opposite corner. 

Hope that makes sense.

AB

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw] At the other end of Little Essex, where it meets Upper Fort Street, there are also missing house numbers. It jumps from No. 96 to No. 102 (see map). This seems to suggest that several properties were resumed to make way for the construction of this section of Little Essex (between Princes and Upper Fort Streets).

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw] Thanks AB, it must have been a typo (scripto?), or maybe Jonh Dogaturdi Jrn was dyslexic !

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: This photo was recently determined to be part of the Rocks Resumption photographic survey, the title and date of the image has been changed accordingly Here is a map of the Rocks Resumption area (last one in the sequence)
